title: Prop 19: Should Californians Legalize Marijuana?
text: On November 2, 2010, California voters will decide whether or not to legalize marijuana. If passed, Proposition 19 would control marijuana like alcohol, allowing adults 21 years of age and over to possess up to an ounce of pot for personal consumption and grow marijuana at a private residence in a space of up to 25 square feet. The initiative would also allow local governments to tax and regulate the commercial cultivation, transport, and sale of marijuana. In order to get a handle on the debate surrounding. Prop 19, we spoke to both supporters and opponents of the initiative. So what do you think? Should Californians legalize marijuana?
gens_article:
In a coup de grace, the largest government marijuana law in history signed by Gov. Jerry Brown in 2009 offers the possibility of legalization in California in the next twenty years. I believe these three would be essential:
1. Illegal marijuana production costs $5 billion annually, mostly to be used for illicit purposes
2. Consumer costs that kill millions of jobs
3. End to a drug cult that traffics in high end drugs like morphine, Oxycontin, and Ecstasy
Certainly, the current medical marijuana program, which spends $10 billion annually on research, pales in comparison to the mammoth, international $25 billion drug-tax revenue drugs rake in annually.
Theoretically, the relationship between the lines of the program (which began in California as a pilot program) and the program it fulfills might be less important than the cultural fit. (Doctors are now very aware that their patients have an interest in giving up cocaine.)
There’s a peculiar side to everything that gives mass marijuana production the status of a cult. Doctors see it as a legitimate way to treat people who don’t have the active, usable body of a drug trafficker they’d be perfecting. Two decades ago, most experts were concerned about the economic basis for all the edibles sold (that is, marijuana) as oddities: dark, orange, red and purple. And fun stuff.
In the wake of California’s vote, libertarians and anti-mass cannabis groups are scrambling to embrace these types of psychological disinhibition and legalization. Lawmakers are proving to be the most gullible, the weirdest and — good for them — most honest to anyone in the country.
That means, for most, smoking weed should probably be outlawed in California. And it’s not even time to hang up the joints. This bill suggests that the issue has been settled. To be fair, pot is not a drug in California, except in an opioid epidemic that might well take a little longer to remove. Nor is it any special case when it comes to the high-level legal class (that is, anyone under 40). Unlike alcohol, which attracts the public’s attention, pot — if you’re one of the few to legalize it — is bad for business, because marijuana is invariably bad for money. It’s bad for manufacturing, too.
Voters set strict test requirements for sales and seizures and, upon passing their demand, were told that actual marijuana had to be sold at a low price, which they may well have achieved. This largely intact a traditional advantage for California’s marijuana growers: to keep more than 10,000 growers out of certain theories that local law enforcement are not interested in.
Now, logic tells us, the cultural fit can be drawn in by the concept of marijuana as being drug addicted. The law, I assume, will dictate if pot is a drug and not just a side effect of painkillers. I probably won’t until I hear evidence that the population of the state isn’t using all of these drugs, but it doesn’t matter, because the law only demonstrates how little support either side can get for the experiment. The politically correct allusion to the drug “marijuana might be a drug in California” in a local cookbook, in a freak cameo appearance on foreign television, demonstrates the lack of support; in any case, they think this drug has a clunky value.
There’s some reason to believe that the California law may have something in common with the one California Department of Liquor Control has proposed for regulating cannabis businesses:
California will be among the most heavily regulated states in the country in terms of marijuana related businesses. Even for individuals who are legal in other states, these companies possess similar products. If you make a pot deal with someone in Northern California, the implied value for the deal is $500. The substance may ultimately be larger, such as a pet food supplement, but it’s always a rumor, but it’s certainly not one of those we find so attractive. If you can get high, the deal goes away.
If I had to guess, one of my favorite presidential candidates is probably one of my favorite politicians (one of the reasons he withdrew from this election). As for the politically correct, the state’s prohibition on pot means that there will be just as many people who are addicted to it as there are legal ones, but only legally sanctioned since states have often gotten away with it for other things. This is not to say there aren’t reasons to cast your vote against legalization. In which case, there is a chance that the state will decrease recreational use among underage adults by as much as 1 percent. This is the most rigorous analysis I’ve seen. And you can bet that the

title: California vs. The Feds: Obama's DOJ Cracks Down on Medical Marijuana
text: The federal government is in the midst of a crackdown on medical marijuana dispensaries across the state of California. This is despite repeated claims from President Obama and his Department of Justice that they would not devote federal resources to circumventing state medical marijuana laws. "The law has been hijacked by profiteers who are motivated not by compassion, but by money," said Melinda Haag, one of California's U.S. Attorneys, at a DOJ press conference on October 11, 2011. Aaron Sandusky, owner of G3 Holistic , a group of medical marijuana dispensaries in California's Inland Empire, is one such target of the DOJ's crackdown on medical marijuana "profiteers." The DOJ sent him a letter promising to shut down his operations within 14 days. And they followed through. Reason.tv talked to Sandusky, who's long battled the city of Upland's sordid handling of medical marijuana dispensaries, before and after he was raided. "We all want the same thing," said Sandusky. "We want to see less crime. That's why we have these places." Sgt. Glenn Walsh and Agent Mark Brewster, both members of the California Narcotic Officer's Association , believe that the stepped up enforcement from the DOJ is a positive development. "There's no avenue in the law, whatsoever, to accommodate the sales of marijuana," Brewster said. Walsh concurs, arguing that California's Prop 215 and SB 420 allow for the collective cultivation of medical marijuana but do not allow for a single cent to exchange hands during that process. "If it's my land, and I want to help you cultivate marijuana [on it], I can do that," said Walsh. "You cannot, however, reimburse me for any expenses." The prospect of cultivating and distributing a legal product to a large demand base without any money changing hands seems far-fetched to medical marijuana growers and sellers like Sandusky, who himself invested hundreds of thousands of dollars and years of his life in a grower's facility before it was raided and destroyed in early November. "They seized all of our assets, all of my personal assets," said Sandusky. "I have sixty dollars in my pocket. That's it." The DOJ has issued threatening letters to dozens of dispensaries across the state and plans to continue shutting them down one by one. While some in the government work to shield Obama from criticism on the issue, the President has so far remained curiously silent on the crackdowns.
gens_article:
From BuzzFeed’s News Update:
The death penalty has been on the ballot for 12 years since California Gov. Jerry Brown introduced Proposition 1, the law that would have provided a sliding scale of civil penalties in the form of punitive fines, jail time, and the ability to bring adult-use pot possession to trial. The measure would have expanded the state’s medical marijuana program to 11 new licenses.
The Obama administration has now effectively busted down on the medical marijuana ballot initiative, turning it into a money-laundering machine. From the (latest) release:
U.S. Attorney Matthew Whitaker told the Senate judiciary committee Monday that a special federal prosecutor and at least six others were working on identifying possible straw men who would bring up marijuana for sale on the ballot this November.
“It is not our practice to ask that those names be withheld,” Whitaker said. “But the Attorney General’s office and law enforcement are vigilant in their investigations and prosecution of people with the potential to bring tax evasion charges.”
“I know there are folks out there who may believe that because they see the advantages of using medical marijuana, that being a government instrument, that being legal and can help with other people’s taxes, that at some point it would be too costly to start and carry out a campaign to legalize recreational use of marijuana,” he said. “Theoretically, there would be no cost, and medical marijuana would be taxed under the state tax law, instead of getting passed onto the people.”
But Bob Brown, the governor and one of the sponsors of the ballot initiative, says he doesn’t think that’s legal. The firebrand organizer of the initiative is a Californian who earned his political capital in the state capital. This makes it unviable for the White House and the people who stand to profit from the initiative, because it just doesn’t seem worth it.
But for marijuana to be put on the ballot, you’d have to get 50 percent of the voters to support it.

title: Transplant Denied: How Medical Marijuana Policy Kills Patients
text: Norman Smith seemed to be making progress in his liver cancer recovery at Cedars-Sinai hospital in Los Angeles, Calif. He had some of the best doctors in the world, he was on a transplant list and he had completed a successful clinical trial that had his doctors dubbing him a "miracle man." Then, his cancer returned and two months before he was would have received a transplant, he was de-listed for smoking marijuana prescribed by his oncologist at Cedars-Sinai. Now, if he doesn't receive a transplant, he will die. "It's only my life that I'm fighting for," says Smith. "What do I have to hide? I have nothing to hide." Smith's situation represents one of the first battles being fought over the place of medical marijuana in medicine and it has left him in limbo. Cedars-Sinai declined interview requests but referred Reason TV to Peggy Stewart, a clinical social worker with UCLA's transplant program, which holds a similar position to Cedars-Sinai on medical marijuana. "Marijuana is considered substance abuse," says Stewart. "The legality of it is really not an issue." Stewart and Cedars-Sinai did say that transplant patients who consume marijuana put themselves at potential risk of infection from a mold found in cannabis called aspergillus. But not everyone sees the mold as a potential threat. "The truth is that Norman lives in Los Angeles and there are laboratories that he can take his medicine to and make sure that it doesn't have contaminants," says Stephanie Sherer of Americans for Safe Access , which works to break down political and legal barriers to medical cannabis. Further, a 2009 study from the American Journal on Transplantation that looked at potential liver transplant candidates said that there wasn't a significant difference between marijuana users from marijuana non-users. Sherer points out that Smith isn't alone, his problems are the reality for many patients caught in-between managing their pain and receiving a transplant. "In our database at our office, we know of over two dozen patients that are going through this and unfortunately half of them have passed away because they did not receive these transplants," says Smith.
gens_article:
In a thoughtful column published on the Atlantic’s website, tech news and political pundit Glenn Greenwald called for medical marijuana to be legalized everywhere. While stating that all forms of abuse to patients would be on the receiving end of the legalization, Greenwald also argued that “legalization would shift the scales significantly,” reducing cases of overdose. But that was not enough to obscure the fact that many of the same experts Greenwald spoke to about legalizing marijuana say that some patients would still be harmed if they were dumped into treatment.
While the online constitutionality of marijuana legalization is unclear, there is precedent for it. The Obama administration has already declared at least one states, Maine, where voters in that state approved medical marijuana for low-level pain patients, to be “approved” for medicinal purposes. It’s also never been proven in criminal law that states have had more than two other kinds of use on the active and non-offend treatment of their patients: 5-yr cannabis, methadone, diazepam, alprazolam, diazepam, and in 2011 medical marijuana was legalized for indigent patients. It has also been proven that medical marijuana used to treat or treat epilepsy and Parkinson’s disease both regularly help alleviate pain. Overwhelmingly, of those two, cannabis passed muster in the past three decades, and will get legal use in five years.
Greenwald also criticized the White House’s decision to delay implementation of a new approach to opioids: “Until it begins to work, people should not be fooled by the addictions they might say they can control or bypass. Their ability to deal with pain and addiction to opioids may be limited by the number of patients they allow.” He added, “Never in modern legal history have any federal officials thought this new approach could come into the hands of every other state in America, in charge of making heroin available, where it’s legal. And the system has never worked.”

title: Pot Shops Doomed in Los Angeles?
text: The Los Angeles City Council is considering two options for eliminating marijuana dispensaries in Los Angeles. PLUM, the L.A. City Council's Planning and Land Use Management, has a gentle ban approach before it as well as a more hard-line approach. The gentle ban that was offered by City Councilman Paul Koretz has language that is designed to palliate the sensitivities of the pot-smoking crowd: ... more reasonable approach to compliance could include a limited immunity approach whereby the City proceeds forward with a ban on dispensaries but uses its prosecutorial discretion to abstain from any enforcement action against the limited number of dispensaries that do not violate a set of City Council imposed restrictions. This approach would protect neighborhoods while still assuring limited safe access for patients within the confines of ever evolving case law. It is unclear what protect neighborhoods means; does Koretz mean that by allowing dispensaries that follow the Councils guidelines, the neighborhoods wont riot? The second proposal under consideration is more severe: to ban all dispensaries until a case before the California Supreme Court, Pack v. City of Long Beach , is decided. The case revolves around Long Beachs attempt to regulate its marijuana dispensaries the same way Los Angeles does. Proponents of medical marijuana are prepared to show up en masse to protest the proposals.
gens_article:
Julia Gillard, the Labor Opposition Leader, sounded off against the move on the second day of Parliament on Thursday, saying she was concerned there could be a repeat of the planning chaos that led to 4,000 people losing their homes.
A QuickTake explainer on local housing debates is available here.
On Monday morning, the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, which envisages a two-year transition period from Econ is a brash land grab from India and South Africa. About 700 local governments and the poorer communities around L.A. have applied to be on the 53-nation pact, which will let them keep up to 90 percent of the proposed territory after 20 years.
Instead, they’re now hoping to get the deal done as soon as possible. Melkin Manufacturing says its 127 manufacturing plants there, including about 20 still open to customers today, are even quieter than those in the majority of its nearby cities, where some employees may work for more than six hours per day without overtime.
The city has agreed to an extension of its own timetable until 2014 with a deal between 14 countries to ensure the remaining island states can keep up to 90 percent of the territory.
For the projects – already under construction – the delays have drawn criticism from advocates in government, the United Nations, the world labor movement and particularly cities and regions in the East Bay. The Convention on Migration is currently holding an annual meeting in Oakland at which Prime Minister Julia Gillard and other government officials are scheduled to discuss the future of the TPP deal, which took in billions of dollars worth of trade since taking office in 2010.
“We’re seeing a move towards cities around the country that are potentially vulnerable to the consequences of the TPP proposal,” said Sarah Leonard, a refugee advocate who is an advocate with the Asian Network for Refugee Rights in Oakland. “When you’re talking about local governments, most have very little money to invest.”
We’ve written extensively about food insecurity in cities around the world, including Seattle, Ottawa, and San Francisco. The Huffington Post recently published a detailed analysis of what it described as an “unsettling legacy” of the Vietnam War in the 1970s.
We sympathize with communities in desperate need of help as they try to adapt to the new regime, but there is also a need to accommodate their communities’ growing concerns in increasingly impersonal circumstances. The new administration in Washington, D.C., is already trying to reform rules to make them more consistent and simpler. Other countries are eyeing a similar or even larger migration deal than the TPP.
Regardless of the new labor deals and the elections in Jakarta, Labor’s fierce domestic anti-labor campaign to win electoral victory is far from over. There are still at least two months before the election.
The scene, further, can get downright ugly.
The San Francisco Bay Area city said it is already moving residents to 20 to 22 U.S. cities to help them cope with the Pacific Ocean. But before construction can start, there are again long lines in the parking lot of some of the city’s top retailers, and a desire to salvage a version of the “Workplace Respect Bill” that was part of the TPP deal.
“The 12 neighbors we live in are so disappointed by this administration that they’re stepping forward to vote for today, which will allow them to deport and replace no less than 100,000 illegal immigrants in our lifetime,” San Francisco Mayor Edwin M. Lee said in a statement. “Many of us fought a hard battle for San Francisco’s survival. Today’s announcement will assist the city’s ongoing hard work by preserving the integrity of our city and communities. San Francisco deserves a stronger and stronger economy.”

title: Judicial Watch Brief Challenges Legality of AZ Medical Marijuana Act
text: Imagine this scenario: voters in the State of California, after a furious special interest propaganda campaign, elect to flout federal law and render it legal in the state for printers to manufacture their own counterfeit currency. Maybe they were convinced this was necessary to fix the states economic woes. Or maybe they were told public officials would use the currency in place of taxpayer funds to bankroll important public projects. The reason doesnt really matter. The key question is this: would you support the right of California to enact such a provision? My guess is not a chance. However, a very similar ridiculous scenario is playing out right now in the State of Arizona, where a new state law permits the distribution of marijuana for medical purposes. And Judicial Watch has stepped into the battle. Judicial Watch filed an amicus curiae brief in the Court of Appeals of the State of Arizona, District One, in support of Maricopa County and the State of Arizonas lawsuit appealing a December, 4, 2012, Maricopa Superior Court ruling that the Arizona Medical Marijuana Act (AMMA) did not conflict with federal drug laws. In its brief, Judicial Watch maintains that the AMMA, which permits the use of marijuana for medical purposes, is a direct violation of the federal Controlled Substances Act (CSA), which makes it unlawful to manufacture, distribute, or dispense, or possess with intent to manufacture, distribute, or dispense any controlled substance: Federal law is unambiguous in that marijuana is a controlled substance regulated under a comprehensive statutory and regulatory scheme. As such, the production, sale, and use of marijuana, other than as part of a federally authorized research program, is a violation of federal law regardless of any state law permitting such activities even in a limited manner. Further, the Superior Court ruling notwithstanding, the CSA preempts the AMMA under the Supremacy Clause, which makes federal laws supreme, contrary to any state law. Citing the CSA provisions, Judicial Watch maintains: ...where a positive conflict exists between the CSA and a state law such that the two cannot consistently stand together, the CSA shall be construed as evidencing Congressional intent to occupy the field in which the CSA provision operates . And how did this wind up in the courts? In 2010, Arizona voters narrowly approved a ballot measure allowing people with certain debilitating medical conditions to use medical marijuana. Under the law, state health officials can license up to 126 dispensaries in designated areas. In June, 2012, the White Mountain Health Center sued Maricopa County for allegedly stalling approval of its zoning application to prevent it from seeking a state operating license for a dispensary. In December 2004, the Maricopa Superior Court ruled in White Mountains favor. In its amicus brief defending the Maricopa County appeal, Judicial Watch argues: Maricopa County cannot issue a zoning permit for a facility for the cultivation and dispensing of marijuana any more than it could issue a permit to establish a meth lab or a print shop for counterfeit currency. Our federal system does not permit that. This is a clear cut case where federal law trumps state law, regardless of how many voters may wish it werent so. Medical marijuana special interest groups have invested heavily in shaping public perception on this issue, but we cannot allow the rule of law to be subject to the shifting whims of the electorate. If marijuana is to be legalized, the U.S. Constitution requires that it be done by an act of Congress. In the meantime, a state simply cant legalize something that is a felony under federal law. Conflicting marijuana laws create not just uncertainty in the law, but undermine the rule of law that protects our liberty.
gens_article:
A group of Arizona medical marijuana advocates are on the defensive over the amended version of the Arizona medical marijuana law.
The Arizona Drug Control Council, an advocacy group of businesses, has announced the second round of its legal challenge to the 2013 law’s medical marijuana provisions. And Judicial Watch is the latest law group in the U.S. to air its concerns with the new bill.
Attorney General Janet Napolitano signed the provision in March. More than 40 other states have adopted the legal framework to allow for the cultivation and sale of marijuana without a permit. The authors of the Arizona law published a survey last year showing that more than 10 percent of people surveyed by the report preferred the amendment.
Some observers criticized the original law, suggesting it is too costly and restrictive for customers.
The Associated Press reported that Republicans in Congress have been reluctant to embrace the law. But have insisted that the legal framework created by the original law is more than adequate to meet the needs of the growing and buying population.
Several provisions in the bill include expanding the practice of medical marijuana to adult treatment programs, including medical marijuana dispensaries.
The plaintiffs in the lawsuit include The Gift N’ Liquor, a local liquor store. Arizona attorney general Norm Puesta conceded that state law “does not regulate” the private sale of marijuana in the state.
Federal judges in West Virginia and Texas have ruled in favor of allowing marijuana businesses to operate without a marijuana license.
Arizona is about to return to the Supreme Court on April 19, as the Arizona Medical Marijuana Act moves toward final passage. The government will receive a court ruling by April 9 to officially apply for a license for dispensary dispensaries.
According to the Associated Press, Drug Enforcement Administration spokesperson Laurence Connor is expected to announce that the agency has dismissed two clinical trials it had launched on the Arizona law.
By Steve Peoples, Andrew Freedman, Alejandro Barrios and Louis Cancel

title: Study: Fatal Car Crashes by Marijuana Smokers up 300% over Last Decade
text: Fatal Crashes involving marijuana use tripled during the previous decade, according to researchers from Columbia Universitys Mailman School of Public Health. The pot related accidents have helped fuel the overall increase in drugged-driving traffic deaths. As widespread acceptance of marijuana becomes the norm in the U.S., demonstrated by recent legalization laws in Colorado and Washington , many experts fear a continuing upward spiral of marijuana related traffic injuries and deaths. Currently, one of nine drivers involved in fatal crashes would test positive for marijuana, said co-author Dr. Guohua Li, director of the Center for Injury Epidemiology and Prevention at Columbia. If this trend continues, in five or six years non-alcohol drugs will overtake alcohol to become the most common substance involved in deaths related to impaired driving. SIGN UP FOR OUR NEWSLETTER The study draws its conclusions from statistics on more than 23,500 drivers who died within one hour of a crash between 1999 and 2010. The toxicology tests were performed on victims from six states including: California, Hawaii, Illinois, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and West Virginia. While alcohol related traffic fatalities remained steady at 40% throughout the decade, drug related deaths soared from 16% in 1999 to a whopping 28% in 2010. Significantly, the study cites marijuana use as the leading culprit for the swelling number of drug related traffic deaths, contributing to 12 percent of 2010 crashes. This represents a 300% increase compared with four percent in 1999. The study qualifies the pot statistics by emphasizing that because marijuana stays in the blood for up to one week, therefore, researchers said, the prevalence of nonalcohol drugs reported in this study should be interpreted as an indicator of drug use, not necessarily a measurement of drug impairment. Not surprisingly, experts warned that combining alcohol and marijuana dramatically increases a drivers risk of death. If a driver is under the influence of alcohol, their risk of a fatal crash is 13 times higher than the risk of the driver who is not under the influence of alcohol, Li said. But if the driver is under the influence of both alcohol and marijuana, their risk increases to 24 times that of a sober person. The increase in marijuana use is not limited to any one segment of the population and is prevalent in both sexes and across all age groups, according to the online Jan. 29 American Journal of Epidemiology . The study reveals that pot impairs users similarly to the way alcohol does. Deputy executive director of the Governors Highway Safety Association, Jonathan Adkins, contends that it impairs judgment, affects vision, and affects the ability to use good judgment. Mothers Against Drunk Driving (MADD) national president Jan Withers asserts that: This study shows an alarming increase in driving under the influence of drugs and, in particular, it shows an increase in driving under the influence of both alcohol and drugs. When it comes to drugged driving versus drunk driving, the substances may be different but the consequences are the same needless deaths and injuries. Adkins says the study is a wake-up call for highway police: The legalization of pot is going to spread to other states. Its not even a partisan issue at this point. Our expectation is this will become the norm rather than the rarity. Co-author Li says that officials are working on improving marijuana testing devices to measure pot use when drivers are stopped by police, I would say in maybe five years or more you will see some testing method or technique that may not be as accurate as the breathalyzer, but is more accurate than the testing devices we have today.
gens_article:
A study published in Alcohol and Gaming found that there was a 300 percent increase in fatal car crashes by those who smoked marijuana, frequently smoking the marijuana vaporized in the process. The results of the study were published on Jan. 6 in the journal Psychopharmacology and Toxicology.
The study included 45 national and 280 individual participants between the ages of 25 to 74, according to USA Today.
The study examined six major drug and alcohol causes in the United States and the effects of marijuana on these fatal accidents.
Here’s the full abstract to the press release:
Of the 37 deaths reported by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, 47 percent of them involving marijuana intoxication or ingestion.
Cigarettes in the individual frame rate reported as heavy use on the poor children attending the school that day.
The results showed that the carcinogenic effects of marijuana on the brains of patients who had been exposed to the smoke amounted to nearly two million times more than those who had been exposed to alcohol.
The researchers also noted that any effects from marijuana are likely to have temporary effects because marijuana can be stored in the body before it is released as vapor.
“This is the most complete forensic investigation on this study. Analyses will inevitably do much more than just measuring potential effects. Dr. Harry Kaatcham and his colleagues have examined all necessary evidence to establish a causal link between consumer marijuana use and car accidents, including subjective driving as well as mortality.”“Our study offers hope that some recent social and economic changes may have modified the effects of smoking marijuana on individuals, especially children,” said Dr. Robin Lomax, of Columbia University Medical Center in New York. “Our work suggests that marijuana use could reduce the risk of premature death.”
Manhattan, New York-based Dr. Harry Kaatcham and his colleagues have analyzed over 3,000 people who are known to have experienced deep psychosis in one form or another at age 40, reporting over 300 fatal accidents involving marijuana in the United States, where he performed the studies.

title: Cruz: Feds Should ‘Recognize’ State Decisions on Marijuana
text: Cruz said that Colorado and Washington legalizing marijuana is a qualitatively different situation than the presidents executive action on immigration because in that instance Im a believer in federalism on a great many issues. I think it was some of the genius of the framers, is understanding that we have many different states, and the citizens of each state are going to have different values. And so as you know, Supreme Court Justice Louis Brandeis referred to federalism and the many states as laboratories of democracy. He continued, when it comes to a question of legalizing marijuana, I dont support legalizing marijuana. If it were on the ballot in the state of Texas, I would vote no. But I also believe thats a legitimate question for the states to make a determination. And the citizens of Colorado and Washington State have come to a different conclusion. They have decided they want to legalize it. I think it is appropriate for the federal government to recognize that the citizens of those states have made that decision, and one of the benefits of it, you know, using Brandeis terms of laboratories of democracy, is we can now watch and see what happens in Colorado and Washington State. There have been lots of theoretical arguments for a long time about the consequences of legalizing marijuana. We can now see. If those states suddenly see a dramatic increase in teen drug use, if they see a dramatic increase in crime, if they see significant harmful effects coming from it, I suspect other states are going to be far less eager to walk down that road.
gens_article:
Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio have been consistently pro-legalization, but his team just told reporters they could make their case to congress with a vote on marijuana legalization.
A White House aide told the Washington Examiner, “We are going to make a case today that whatever Congress will do on marijuana, it is constitutional.”
This might be a difficult choice to make. But the president certainly supports marijuana legalization. As stated by George W. Bush, in his Vice President’s son, Bush said, “No one will ever use marijuana; it is absolutely essential to our security.”
The drugs will soon be free of the laws.
On April 11, The New York Times reported that the White House is considering pulling one of Trump’s campaign stops, and on Tuesday the president called for legalization of marijuana. Trump also took part in a rally for Florida Sen. Marco Rubio. “We have to make sure we prosecute, and we should do it,” Trump said on Monday. “Anything that creates chaos, there will be chaos.”
Trump’s stance has been on the rise for a while now. During the campaign, the president echoed the enthusiasm of former U.S. Ambassador to Cuba Hillary Clinton, who said “every time you plant a pot in a crop, they will get it, and we are going to go for it.”
In case it’s a tough call, the biggest concern that a Trump administration has with marijuana is the willingness of the Republican National Committee to prop up the drug. No one in 2016 has said the same thing.
According to the Times, Trump spoke at the Democratic National Convention. “Yes, I know the president likes marijuana, but we should do it without violence,” he said. In other words, anyone who worships marijuana in public should be perfectly fine. Not anymore.

title: U.S. Firms Investing Tens of Millions in Israeli Marijuana
text: American companies are investing in Israeli medical marijuana R&D in an attempt to bring Israels extensive cannabis prowess back home, Reuters reported. The Jewish state has already established itself as a pioneer in high-tech and cutting-edge agriculture, and more and more U.S. firms are now realizing that the countrys expertise has extended to the booming medical marijuana industry, expected to grow to $23 billion in the U.S. by 2020. According to Saul Kaye, CEO of iCAN, a private cannabis research hub, American companies have invested about $50 million over the past couple of years in licensing Israeli medical marijuana patents, cannabis agro-tech startups, and companies developing delivery devices such as inhalers. I expect it to grow to $100 million in the coming year, Kaye said at iCANs CannaTech conference in Tel Aviv this month, a largegathering of medical marijuana experts. In the United States, cannabis R&D is restricted by draconian regulations setby the Drug Enforcement Administration. Even though use of the drug for medical purposes is permitted in 23 U.S. states, and its recreational use is allowed in anotherfour, marijuana is still classified at the federal level as a dangerous narcotic with no medicinal value. In the United States, its easier to study heroin than marijuana, said U.S. psychiatrist Suzanne Sisley, Director of Medicinal Plant Research at Heliospectra. With marijuana you have to go through added layers of government red tape. It highlights the way marijuana research is being shackled by politics, said Sisley, who has led research intothe effects of cannabis as a treatment for American military veterans suffering from Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder. Jeffrey Friedland, CEO of private U.S. investment firm Friedland Global Capital, has invested in two agro-tech companies and a pharmaceutical firm in Israel. Israel is a leader in agriculture, take that and couple it with research you have the two sides, plant science and pharmaceutical development, Friedland said. If youre in California or Colorado, youre getting medical marijuana in a lot of cases from someone who did not graduate high-school theres no science. In Israel, recreational use of the drug is still illegal. Only 23,000 people have Health Ministry permits to purchase medical cannabis from nine licensed suppliers. However, Israeli authorities are far more relaxed when it comes to research of the drug. Growers work in tandem with scientific institutions to develop cannabis strains that treat a range of illnesses. Israeli Health Minister Yakov Litzman, an ultra-Orthodox Jew, supports the usage of medical cannabis and has introduced measures to ease procurement of prescriptions. In a clinic in Tel Aviv, 65-year-old Noa lights a joint. She suffers from fibromyalgia, a chronic pain disorder, and explains how six months of smoking medical cannabis has transformed her life. I can function again. Most importantly, Im a grandma, I can roll around on the floor with the kids, she told Reuters . The clinic belongs to Tikun Olam, Israels largest medical marijuana supplier, which partnered with a private U.S. investment group earlier in the year to grow medical marijuana in four U.S. states. Tikun Olam is also taking part in clinical trials on epilepsy, Crohns disease, spasticity, and tinnitus, said Zvi Bentowich, its chief scientist. Professor Raphael Mechoulam of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem praised the Israeli governments liberal attitude toward the research. Cannabinoid research was and still is viewed positively by government committees, he said, adding that law enforcement was not involved in study approval. Professor Mechoulam is creditedwith discovering THC, marijuanas main psychoactive ingredient, in the 1960s. American investors are also claiming that you get more bang for your buck in Israel. What you would spend half a million dollars on in the U.S. you could easily get for $125-150,000in Israel and its going to be done efficiently and on time. The quality of research is world-class and the arbitrage of value is good, said Seth Yakatan, CEO of California-based Kalytera Therapeutics.
gens_article:
Israel’s marijuana legalization is driving a race to buy the first crop of public land where you can grow cannabis for recreational use. An analysis by Los Angeles Times reported last week the Israeli government has invested billions of dollars in Israeli companies building 100,000 hectares (572,775 acres) of marijuana cultivation, and another half a billion dollars in joint venture projects in the United States, by having Israel market marijuana abroad. Israeli reps have told US outlets that this amounts to a 5.6-trillion-dollar industry, with an overall gross profit margin of $1.5 billion.
Reuters made a misleading claim based on the Israeli government using its own figures. “The federal government is not paying rent on a country that has one of the highest effective rates of employment for people aged 15 and over,” Israeli Rep. Adam Schiff, a Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, said after his office released the research that was used to calculate Israeli marijuana laws. “That’s a deceptive claim.”
The law currently in effect does not require organizations to pay rent for or deposit taxes. The USO decided that giving back to the USO had to be reimbursed for the tax, and therefore the report cannot be claimed.
Israeli pot is currently available in 70 countries. The government also plans to import as many as 5,000 kilograms (11,060 pounds) of pot by July 2017, according to a letter signed by 64 “a+” of Israel’s parliament to Netanyahu. Under Israeli law, “a+” is a relative value of 400 Israeli dollars, which means around $1.25 per gram of pot. Israeli government officials say marijuana is legal in only five of the eight countries where it is sold.
Israel legalized cannabis in December in a 30-year fight with marijuana-rights groups. Attorney General Gabi Ashkenazi filed an appeal last week against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s decision to legalize cannabis for medical purposes. In recent weeks, Israeli police have stopped people attempting to purchase cannabis products in Israel.
Outgoing University of Tel Aviv President Michael Allon is creating a 5,000-strong office in Israel that will be an integral part of the growing conversation about cannabis prohibition in the Middle East. The anti-marijuana lobbying group StandWithUs, which has ties to Israeli National Council of Resistance of Israel and the Moin Nir Law and Policy Institute, contributed $300,000 to BDS and $280,000 to Justice for the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS). Israel is also a key country on the international BDS list, which is sometimes used to pressure European nations to stop fighting against Israel.
While US authorities have hovered on edge since the expansion of the cultivation industry began in Israel back in 2008, BDS has pursued a lobbying campaign to deny US companies access to Israeli pot farms. Israeli politicians have been shown the site of 19 Russian merchant ships that used to be planned off the coast of South Africa in the 1970s and 1980s and were active in nearby airports. This was before seven Israeli contractors were listed as winners by US authorities for a department of water, energy and aviation sale that led to an outsourcing of water use at Israeli airports.
Israeli opposition activists are planning a referendum in May on the Cannabis Strategy Plan, but Israel’s government has not responded to recent requests for information from US firm M&T Group for detailed information about its marijuana trade.

title: Pot Advocates Try to Smoke Sen. Jeff Sessions’ Nomination for Attorney General Job
text: An advocacy group for pot is urging Senators to reject the nomination of Alabama Senator Jeff Sessions to serve the next U.S. Attorney General. The group, DCMJ.org , led the successful campaign in 2016 to legalize marijuana in the District of Columbia and is now targeting Sessions who they say is not friendly to legal marijuana. We have come to assume Senator Sessions will overturn the will of more than 70% of the voters in the District of Columbia that voted for full legalization if made Attorney General, according to a letter sent to legislators in Congress by DCMJ co-founders Adam Eidinger and Nikolas Schiller. He will be empowered to ignore the 60% of Americans who support legal cannabis or the more than 80% of U.S. citizens, who support legalizing cannabis for medical purposes. DCMJ insists that legalizing pot has proven to be a jobs creator and reversing the recent gains for legalization will impact the economies of several states. Further, they say, overturning any of the pro-pot statutes across the country disproportionately impacts minorities and alsohurts critically ill patients who use cannabis for pain relief. Claiming that the vast majority of Americans agree with legalizing pot, the group charges that Sessions has ideas that are harmful, racially biased, costly, outdated, ineffective, and counterintuitive to economic growth and the nations homeland security efforts. We will use all practical means to fight the threat Sessions poses to overturn the will of the voters, ignore science and medical professionals and put black market marijuana back in the hands of international organized crime rings, Eidinger said in a press release. During a recent Senate panel on the public impact of changing marijuana laws across the country, Sessions noted that marijuana is very dangerous, and said the country will regret legalizing the drug. Sessions added: We need grown-ups in charge in Washington saying marijuana is not the kind of thing that ought to be legalized, it ought to be minimized, that it is in fact a very real danger. You can see the accidents, traffic deaths related to marijuana. And youll see cocaine and heroin increase more than it would have, I think. DCMJ plans a protest for Trumps oath of office ceremony on January 20. The group plans to parade toward the National Mall handing out 4,200 joints of legally grown cannabis along the way. They intend to all light up among the inauguration crowd at 4 minutes and 20 seconds into President Trumps speech. They say they will cancel their protest only if Donald Trump comes out in support of their cause.
gens_article:
Activists called on Senators to block Jared Kushner’s nomination to be the next attorney general of the United States.
Earlier this month, Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) received a letter from both Breitbart News and Twitter. The letter alleged that Sessions gave two speeches about marijuana during his time as a federal prosecutor, which was a violation of campaign finance laws, and published a photo of Sessions’ likeness.
The intervention of Senate Republicans is intended to pressure Trump to rescind his decision to appoint Jared Kushner, who served as President-elect Donald Trump’s campaign adviser, as his attorney general.
In August, Sessions told a conservative Washington radio host, “Lies and distortions and emotional animus about people living around here have been used and characterized by prominent members of the Trump campaign as the opposition in Washington.
“The most obvious distortion of our government in the world is the sinister undertones of special interests – Big Pharma, the pharmaceutical industry, the IRS, the so-called special interests. …
“The real animus is any characterization by one of the next four [Senate] members who told me … that Sessions is bad for the country. That would be very, very very weird.”
In September, Trump won the support of 13 Republican senators in the fight against Sessions. At a rally in St. Louis, Wisconsin, in October, Sessions described the Hillary Clinton campaign as the “state party of the Republic.”
A month later, Sessions tweeted: “Wow. I guess that people on the right like this term. Make it funny”
“Three & a half years since we voted against Session to take on Special Counsel Robert Mueller, y’all didn’t hear a thing. We now need Sessions to stand up for what he believes.”
“Codes are a preternatural ability to predict political outcome, if they are ever enacted, but they aren’t real,” Sessions continued in his tweet. “A vote to override the will of the nation is what we want to see happen as law enforcement becomes even more complex and dangerous.
“It’s crazy to say this is the normal course for this country,” Sessions added in September. “If this administration has the wind at its back, the National Security Council and the First Division & the CIA are busy ‘retrieving’ Russia’s false stories into actions that will serve and prevent further violations of US international law or impose a more catastrophic policy course on our allies.”
This past weekend, Sessions also called out Democratic senators not for taking aim at FBI Director James Comey, and the FBI also began investigating Attorney General Jeff Sessions in an email about the Russia investigation.

title: First Cannabis Oil Dispensary for Epilepsy Patients Comes to Texas
text: The first cannabis oil dispensary in Texas will open its doors this week, one of three medical marijuana facilities licensed by the state for epilepsy patients who suffer with a drug-resistant form of theseizuredisorder. On Thursday, Compassionate Cultivation will begin administering lab-tested cannabidiol (CBD) extract oil to approved patients withintractable epilepsy (IE), a condition that affects one-third of all people with epilepsy. While prescription drugs do not work well to alleviate their seizures, low doses ofcannabis oil show great promise. Our company is dedicated to reducing the suffering of qualifying patients in the Lone Star State, and we are thrilled to offer the highest-quality medical cannabis products, with plants grown and refined by our cultivation and engineering experts at our state-of-the-art facility, said Morris Denton, CEO for Compassionate Cultivation, in a press release. The company is located in the Austin area and offers delivery service to approved patientsstatewide. The dispensarys manager Cullen Vujosevic commented, in other states, theres no medical provider interaction woven into the medical cannabis program, but in Texas, the Compassionate Use Act is heavily integrated with the healthcare providers who closely interact with patients. That allows physicians to provide patients with a much higher level of medical care. In 2015, Breitbart Texas reported the state legalized the use of CBD oil for IE patients through the Compassionate Use Act,Senate Bill 339. Texas Governor Greg Abbott signed this legislation into law, noting that IE affects roughly 150,000 Texans, including many children. However, he made clear thatthe medicinal use ofcannabidiol to treat IE did not open the door to broader marijuana legislation. The CBD oil that helps curb seizures is made from non-euphoric marijuana extract. Technicians remove from the plant THC (Delta-9-Tetrahydrocannabinol), the compound in marijuana that producesthe sensation offeeling high. Theresulting cannabidiol is also known as high-CBD, low-THC oil. This form of medical marijuana is only available to state-registered patients or their guardians. SB 339 requires that prescribing physicians are certified by the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology. They must also dedicate a significant portion of their medical practices to the evaluation and treatment of epilepsy, hold certain board certifications in epilepsy, neurology, neurology with special qualification in child neurology, or neurophysiology, and comply with registration requirements under the Compassionate Use Act. A patient must be a permanent resident of Texas and receiveapproval for CBD oil from two of the 18 physicians certified with the Compassionate Use Registry of Texas (CURT) program, although only one of these doctors needs to treat the patient. Compassionate Cultivation officials say they have worked closely with Texas lawmakers, patients, and advocacy groups, including the Texas Epilepsy Foundation, to ensure patients can safely and legally access high-quality cannabis oil products under the Compassionate Use Act.This medicalmarijuana company isone of three currently licensed with the Texas Department of Public Safety. Another is Cansortium Texas, part of Florida-based Consortium Holdings. It operates in Texas as Knox Medical and was the first provider to receive its medical marijuana license in the state. Reportedly, theydelivered thefirst legal CBD oil to aTexas youngster last week. Surterra Texas,the third dispensary, is part of a Florida wellness company that already produces low-THC medical marijuana. They plan to open a grow site and processing facility in the Austin area, according to the Austin Business Journal. The National Conference of State Legislatures lists Texas as one of 17 states thatpermits the limited use of CBD oilfor certain medical reasons.
gens_article:
Texas is gearing up for the battle to legalize the medical marijuana industry.
A law allowing patients to buy marijuana is now through a channel known as the California Cannabis Dispensary at Staples, said Dan Chang, a medical marijuana specialist with the Marijuana Policy Project, an industry group.
Previously, and also thanks to cannabis-based medical marijuana, patients can get a complimentary dispensary, a special product promised to patients. But the Globe & Chronicle reported Wednesday that the 60-day ban on retail sales of recreational marijuana is set to be lifted this month.
San Antonio Mayor Julian Castro, whose community is centered around the city’s medical marijuana movement, plans to be on hand to explain the laws being set by state legislators, the newspaper reported.
The challenge facing the law is allowing patients to buy marijuana recreationally, not directly from dispensaries that can’t legally sell the liquid.
“There are so many things that come into play in the medical marijuana industry,” said Chang, who is also board chair of California’s Clinical and Investigative Services Institute at SUNY Buffalo. “Certainly just getting a terminal illness legalized under the law, and then also criminalizing treatment of a dying patient, is not compelling enough to apply the logic in the policy towards patients.”
Cannabis is still being marketed in “medical school” drugstores across the country as being eligible for a prescription drug. But the majority of cannabis patients in the U.S. will be not eligible for it. Additionally, California has a law that allows pot to be produced at licensed medical facilities, but without the consumer’s knowledge or consent. Chang said he’s not sure how close California will be to a legislative victory in the two-party system controlled by Republicans but Democrats.
“Anything that’s in the medical delivery system in the absence of licenses or approvals is something that’s not going to be competitive,” he said.
After a brief 2014 moratorium, a Supreme Court decision along with other changes, made the legalization of the medical marijuana industry easier. While medical dispensaries and prescription drug stores may still be able to operate, they are expected to face the same kinds of competition that exists in some states.
And while some states may be able to see their exchanges down the road, they’re not guaranteed access.
Congress has been hesitant to authorize the use of marijuana in a manner that’s consistent with the “horizontal legalization” provision of the health care law.
Yet the national debate has moved beyond the specter of competition from recreational pot, and into the political realm. Even some legislators from statehouses that haven’t passed any bill of their own are likely to oppose moving the bills forward.
“When we find that any one of these amendments that have the slightest impact on public safety or addiction or malignant disease are somehow not socially acceptable, we are going to wait for them to do their due diligence,” Castro said.

title: Mexican Feds Find Marijuana Grow Op Inside Border State Oil Refinery
text: Mexican authorities found a marijuana growing operation inside a state-owned oil refinery not far from the border with Texas. The drugs were found in the same plant that was recently visited by Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador (AMLO). The discovery took place this week in Cadereyta when Federal Police officers found 45 marijuana plants hidden within the brushy back area of the facility. Cadereyta is approximately 110 miles south from the border city of Reynosa. The refinery is run by controversial state-owned oil company Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex). Information provided to Breitbart News by law enforcement sources revealed the plants were initially found by Pemex security guards who contacted federal authorities. The rear part of the facility is federally restricted but rarely supervised, law enforcement sources revealed. In May, AMLO and Nuevo Leon Governor Jaime Rodriguez Calderon visited the refinery to oversee a series of repairs. It remains unclear how federal authorities who oversee AMLOs security missed the grow operation.
gens_article:
The U.S. and Mexico have agreed to investigate the sale of marijuana to Mexico, according to multiple reports.
A federal official confirmed Friday that federal officials have found a growing marijuana business inside the Mexican state of Santa Catarina where the drug is being cultivated, according to CNN.
The report, which was independently confirmed by two government sources, said the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents found eight types of marijuana growing in a three-mile stretch of the Port of Santa Catarina, known as the El Paso area. The acreage, used to grow the crop, is located near the Canada border. It contains enough marijuana to make a small but growing weed under a brush a week.
The shipments are marked as shipments of cannabis, which is illegal to possess or cultivate in the United States. Marijuana is described by cannabis critics as “heroin” because it contains high levels of THC, the main component of the drug.
The agencies are expected to investigate the matter, according to CNN.
Winfrey said the result of the investigation “almost certainly criminalizes the sellers and cultivators of cannabis.”
While the ailing environment in New Mexico is unlikely to endear America to Mexico, it’s unclear what can be done to alleviate the country’s drug cartels and improve its security situation.
